awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Collaborative Research: Understanding linkages between nutrient quality and phytoplankton assemblage responses to COVID-19 stay-at-home orders in an urban, estuarine system
awd_abstract_narration:
In addition to health and safety concerns, the global coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic has had significant impacts on human behavior worldwide, from business and school closures to stay-at-home orders. As a consequence there have been unprecedented and precipitous drops in global travel for work, education, recreation, and other daily activities. The associated declines in fossil fuel consumption and pollution emissions have resulted in improved air quality. Reductions in atmospheric contaminants (particularly nitrogen, N) and deposition of pollutants must also be influencing nutrient cycling and impacting terrestrial and aquatic ecosystem processes. The situation has created a completely novel and large-scale "human experiment" in how sudden changes in socio-economic behavior and mobility patterns may influence the environment. To better understand environmental changes associated with the pandemic, this NSF RAPID project will focus on studies of coastal and estuary aquatic habitats, which are known to be particularly biologically productive and diverse. Researchers will measure key biogeochemical (nutrient) and ecological (phytoplankton, bacteria) metrics using water sampling and satellite observations of an urban estuary on the east coast of the US over the COVID-19 shutdown and reopening periods. This project will also train postdoctoral scholars and graduate students, including those from underrepresented groups in science, while enhancing the understanding of connections between societal activity and coastal ecosystems.

Steep declines in the concentration, thus deposition, of atmospheric pollution (particularly N), combined with shifts in wastewater effluent distribution associated with the COVID-19 shut-down are expected to influence the biogeochemistry and ecology of adjacent coastal waters. Since the dominant N-form, and stoichiometric ratios relative to other nutrients, shape phytoplankton and bacterial community structure, sudden changes in nutrient amounts, quality, and source distribution in an urban estuary could translate to regime shifts in microbial assemblages and biogeochemical processes. The overarching hypothesis of this study is that the sudden decline in human activity due to the COVID-19 pandemic will exert considerable and measurable effects on coastal biogeochemical and physical water quality parameters as well as phytoplankton and bacterial assemblages. While this hypothesis is broadly applicable to developed coastlines worldwide, this study will focus on Long Island Sound (LIS) because it (i) borders the greater New York City (NYC) metropolitan area, specifically the commuting corridor between NY and Connecticut (CT), (ii) is heavily urbanized, (iii) was especially hard-hit by COVID-19, and (iv) NY and CT were among the first states to mandate stay-at-home restrictions, leading to surrounding communities drastically downscaling transportation activity. The research addresses three questions: 1. Have recent changes in human activity (improved air quality and concurrent changes in wastewater inputs) been associated with shifts in key biogeochemical metrics (C, N, P, Si) and stoichiometric ratios? 2. What are the corresponding responses of phytoplankton and bacterial assemblages? 3. How do these changes relate to shifts in bio-optical properties? To answer these timely ecosystem-scale questions, the team will measure key water quality and biogeochemical parameters, as well as evaluate the abundances and composition of phytoplankton and bacterial assemblages. Work will leverage regional water and air quality monitoring and past and ongoing water sampling in LIS. Satellite ocean color imagery will be used to scale-up observations from point measurements to the larger ecosystem.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: The emergence of the highly contagious coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic led to world-wide stay-at-home orders. Consequently, there were unprecedented and precipitous drops in global travel (e.g. vehicle, airline, train, ship) for work, recreation, and other daily activities.  Associated declines in fossil fuel consumption and pollution emissions resulted in substantial improved air quality, particularly in urban areas. In coastal cities, related reductions in atmospheric pollution (particularly nitrogen, N) and deposition of pollutants likely influenced nutrient delivery to coastal ecosystems, thus ecosystem function. In addition to direct air quality improvements, the spatial distributions of N-rich wastewater effluent discharges in to receiving coastal waterways were impacted. Combined, these events created a completely novel ‘human experiment’ in how sudden changes in socio-economic behavior and mobility patterns influenced surrounding aquatic environments. The overarching study hypothesis was that the sudden decline in human activity due to the COVID-19 shutdown exerted considerable and measurable effects on coastal biogeochemical and physical water quality parameters as well as phytoplankton and bacterial assemblages. While the study hypothesis was likely applicable to developed coastlines worldwide, this research focused on Long Island Sound (LIS), home to nine million people relying on its abundant resources (shellfish, tourism, commerce) and one of the most heavily urbanized coastal areas of North America.  LIS also (i) borders the greater New York City (NYC) metropolitan area, specifically the extensive commuting corridor between NY and Connecticut (CT), (ii) is heavily urbanized, (iii) was particularly hard-hit by COVID-19, and (iv) NY and CT were among the first states to mandate stay-at-home restrictions to slow the spread of COVID-19, leading to surrounding communities drastically downscaling transportation activity. The densely-populated LIS region is associated with decades of N-enrichment to its waterways from wastewater and other sources causing a host of environmental issues such as seasonal hypoxia, algal blooms, and ecosystem disruption. To address our study hypothesis, we measured key biogeochemical (nutrient), bio-optical (FDOM, CDOM), and ecological (phytoplankton, bacteria) metrics using water sampling and satellite observations from the LIS shore and mainstem over the COVID-19 shutdown and phased reopening. The field design spanned an urban (NYC) to suburban (CT) gradient as well as leveraged ongoing regional water and air quality monitoring efforts for both sample collection and historical data.

 

Research Findings: By combining field measurements with in situ nutrient addition bioassay experiments testing phytoplankton responses to nutrients spikes at pre-COVID concentrations, we showed that decreases in nitrate-N were accompanied by minimal changes in ammonia-N. These shifts in inorganic N-form altered diatom and flagellate species abundances, with nitrate increasing diatom concentrations relative to cryptophyte and euglenoids whereas ammonia-N had an over-riding inhibitory effect. Conversely, euglenoids and crytophytes were more abundant when nitrate was low, indicating that inorganic N reductions during COVID-19 likely modified phytoplankton community composition, despite transient influences on overall phytoplankton biomass. Similar trends were noted in our field observations, as nitrate levels were positively associated with diatom abundances, except in cases with elevated ammonia-N (such as stations located near wastewater inputs). In those instances, flagellates and smaller (nano- and picoplankton-sized) cells prevailed.

Space-based observations, at the ecosystem scale, uniquely captured how disparate changes in anthropogenic pressure (atmospheric and wastewater pollution) between NYC and LIS resulted in contrasting regional COVID-19 water-quality impacts in our study. High spatial resolution satellite retrievals from Sentinel-3/OLCI, Landsat/OLI and Senitnel-2/MSI revealed short-term improvements in water quality (lower turbidity and colored dissolved organic matter) in response to stay-at-home orders in spring 2020 in NY Harbor’s Upper Bay, where nitrogen loadings significantly decreased from pre-pandemic levels. Along with decreased turbidity in the Upper Bay, satellite observations showed increases in chlorophyll-a late spring and summer 2020, suggesting an alleviation in light limitation. The continued pervasiveness of remote work and multiple waves of the pandemic into 2021 maintained lower atmospheric pollution and nitrogen loadings from WWTFs, resulting in improved water clarity in the Upper Bay through summer 2021. Across LIS, however, changes in anthropogenic pressure had a less observable impact on water quality trends. These observations support that not only by reducing overall wastewater input to NYC’s waters, but targeting ammonia-N reductions in particular could lead to direct improvements in overall water quality.

 

Broader Impacts: The project entailed substantial training in scholarship, mentorship, and career development opportunities for students, postdocs, and research professionals to equip team members with multiple skills necessary to succeed in STEM careers. The City University of New York is the largest US urban university with some of the country’s most ethnically and culturally diverse campuses, including Minority and Hispanic Serving Institutions. Accordingly, this study involved 4 undergraduate and 5 graduate students, 2 postdocs, and 2 Research Associates spanning a wide spectrum of cultural, racial, and social identities who conducted the majority of sample collection, analysis, and data synthesis activities. Members of this talented group served as lead authors for most study outputs.
